Section title on Readme page.

trans-unit.source: Our ambitions in creating _Photo Club Hub_ were to strengthen ties between photography clubs, and making the work of members easier to access.
trans-unit.target: Our ambitions in creating _Photo Club Hub_ were to strengthen ties between photography clubs, and making the work of members easier to access.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: _Photo Club Hub_ showcases selected photos by members of participating clubs. The photos are displayed in a consistent, easy to access way, with minimal distractions.
trans-unit.target: _Photo Club Hub_ showcases selected photos by members of participating clubs. The photos are displayed in a consistent, easy to access way, with minimal distractions.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: This consistent presentation of photographs avoids having to find each club's website, and then figuring out how to locate and browse the images. The app does not try to replace either club web sites, photographer web sites. or social media use. Instead, it facilitates clubs and their members in reaching other clubs, other photographers, and a general audience.
trans-unit.target: This consistent presentation of photographs avoids having to find each club's website, and then figuring out how to locate and browse the images. The app does not try to replace either club web sites, photographer web sites. or social media use. Instead, it facilitates clubs and their members in reaching other clubs, other photographers, and a general audience.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app was originally named _Photo Club Waalre_ after a 15-person photo club in the Netherlands. The word __hub__ in the new name stresses the app's support for __multiple__ photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: The app was originally named _Photo Club Waalre_ after a 15-person photo club in the Netherlands. The word __hub__ in the new name stresses the app's support for __multiple__ photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Supporting many clubs requires that individual clubs maintain their own data. This includes providing images, and maintaining club membership lists. Adding a club to _Photo Club Hub_ does not require software expertise.
trans-unit.target: Supporting many clubs requires that individual clubs maintain their own data. This includes providing images, and maintaining club membership lists. Adding a club to _Photo Club Hub_ does not require software expertise.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Interested in adding support for your photo club? Contact us via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/vdhamer) or [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vdhamer/). Adding your club only involves maintaining your data in a way that the app can read it. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the strategy and approach. We are here to help if you have any questions.
trans-unit.target: Interested in adding support for your photo club? Contact us via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/vdhamer) or [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vdhamer/). Adding your club only involves maintaining your data in a way that the app can read it. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the strategy and approach. We are here to help if you have any questions.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Photo clubs play a central role in this app. The _Portfolios_ screen shows a list of photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: Photo clubs play a central role in this app. The _Portfolios_ screen shows a list of photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Each photo club contains a series of member portfolios holding the actual images.
trans-unit.target: Each photo club contains a series of member portfolios holding the actual images.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Each portfolio covers the photographer's photos that are associated with that photo club. A photographer may have multiple portfolios in the app in case the photographer is (or was) associated with more than one photo club.
trans-unit.target: Each portfolio covers the photographer's photos that are associated with that photo club. A photographer may have multiple portfolios in the app in case the photographer is (or was) associated with more than one photo club.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Just like a painter, a photographer’s style may change over the years. Each portfolio is therefore shown in chronological order, with the latest work first.
trans-unit.target: Just like a painter, a photographer’s style may change over the years. Each portfolio is therefore shown in chronological order, with the latest work first.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: We aim to show the portfolios with minimal distraction, just like an exposition at a museum or gallery. Web sites tend to be less optimal for this, because they are cluttered by browser controls—an address bar or tabs—and have to serve multiple purposes, like displaying club news or meeting dates.
trans-unit.target: We aim to show the portfolios with minimal distraction, just like an exposition at a museum or gallery. Web sites tend to be less optimal for this, because they are cluttered by browser controls—an address bar or tabs—and have to serve multiple purposes, like displaying club news or meeting dates.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Languages__\n\n_Photo Club Hub_ automatically selects its language based on your device’s language settings. It currently supports English and Dutch. You can change language using _Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_ or by overruling this setting for this app only (_Settings > Photo Club Hub > Language_).
trans-unit.target: __Languages__\n\n_Photo Club Hub_ automatically selects its language based on your device’s language settings. It currently supports English and Dutch. You can change language using _Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_ or by overruling this setting for this app only (_Settings > Photo Club Hub > Language_).
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __3D maps__\n\nIf you zoom in enough on any map, a button appears that allows you do view building heights. In this mode you can rotate the map.
trans-unit.target: __3D maps__\n\nIf you zoom in enough on any map, a button appears that allows you do view building heights. In this mode you can rotate the map.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__Live location__

Maps can show you your live location as a purple dot when it’s in range of the map. This can help navigate to a club or to estimate distances. If the map is unlocked/interactive, a arrow button can re-center the map around your current location.

Live location requires granting the app __permission__ to access your location while in the app. The app doesn’t store or share location information with anyone or anything.
trans-unit.target:
__Live location__

Maps can show you your live location as a purple dot when it’s in range of the map. This can help navigate to a club or to estimate distances. If the map is unlocked/interactive, a arrow button can re-center the map around your current location.

Live location requires granting the app __permission__ to access your location while in the app. The app doesn’t store or share location information with anyone or anything.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__Adding photo clubs__

The app contains a set of initial photo clubs. Those photo clubs are so far all in one region of the Netherlands. Clubs anywhere in the world can can be added country, regardless whether they are part of some larger photo club federation.

This requires extending an online (.json) file. For now this involves sending us the club’s name, town, latitude, and longitude. And, if possible, providing a web address and a remark in one or more languages (140 char each) on anything noteworthy about the club. There examples in an extended [Readme](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) on GitHub.

Adding and maintaining membership lists for a photo club is a feature for a __future__ app update. These “memberList” files can be hosted on your __own__ website. There will be instructions by then on how to do this for WordPress users, but anything that results in a URL to a valid memberList (JSON) file will work.
trans-unit.target:
__Adding photo clubs__

The app contains a set of initial photo clubs. Those photo clubs are so far all in one region of the Netherlands. Clubs anywhere in the world can can be added country, regardless whether they are part of some larger photo club federation.

This requires extending an online (.json) file. For now this involves sending us the club’s name, town, latitude, and longitude. And, if possible, providing a web address and a remark in one or more languages (140 char each) on anything noteworthy about the club. There examples in an extended [Readme](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) on GitHub.

Adding and maintaining membership lists for a photo club is a feature for a __future__ app update. These “memberList” files can be hosted on your __own__ website. There will be instructions by then on how to do this for WordPress users, but anything that results in a URL to a valid memberList (JSON) file will work.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__Photo museums__

The maps can show various photo museums throughout the world. They have a different icon than photo clubs. Museums show up if you zoom out any map far enough that they come into view.

Adding a photo museum works the same way as adding a photo club - except that a museum doesn’t have members and member portfolios.
trans-unit.target:
__Photo museums__

The maps can show various photo museums throughout the world. They have a different icon than photo clubs. Museums show up if you zoom out any map far enough that they come into view.

Adding a photo museum works the same way as adding a photo club - except that a museum doesn’t have members and member portfolios.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__Deleting members (and more)__

On the _Portfolios_ screen you can delete a club member by swiping the row to the left. Other screens have similar functionality for removing individual photographers and clubs.

Deletion of an arbitrary member will generally be __temporary__ because the member is still on the club's online membership lists. Deletion does have effect if the row has been deleted from these online lists. The feature will be automated at some point, and is only useful in special circumstances (like when a typo in a member's name is corrected).

So just remember that swiping left is harmless, and if you need to clean up a list you can alternatively just uninstall and reinstall the app to clean up the app's internal data.
trans-unit.target:
__Deleting members (and more)__

On the _Portfolios_ screen you can delete a club member by swiping the row to the left. Other screens have similar functionality for removing individual photographers and clubs.

Deletion of an arbitrary member will generally be __temporary__ because the member is still on the club's online membership lists. Deletion does have effect if the row has been deleted from these online lists. The feature will be automated at some point, and is only useful in special circumstances (like when a typo in a member's name is corrected).

So just remember that swiping left is harmless, and if you need to clean up a list you can alternatively just uninstall and reinstall the app to clean up the app's internal data.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Web sites__\n\nThis app is complimentary to your club’s web site. Because web sites have more uses than just presenting photos, _Photo Club Hub_ includes clickable links to club and photographer web sites.
trans-unit.target: __Web sites__\n\nThis app is complimentary to your club’s web site. Because web sites have more uses than just presenting photos, _Photo Club Hub_ includes clickable links to club and photographer web sites.
trans-unit.note: Seventh paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__The opening image__

When the app opens, it shows an image (“Prelude”) corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere __inside__ the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.

This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that adds a color filter on top of each sensor cell. This filter array is shown superimposed on a colorful photo.

Tapping __inside__ the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping __outside__ the image area ends the animation. A single tap __outside__ the image allows you to skip the animation.

The animation incidentally uses GPU core acceleration using the [Metal software framework](https://browser.geekbench.com/ios-benchmarks#metal).
trans-unit.target:
__The opening image__

When the app opens, it shows an image (“Prelude”) corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere __inside__ the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.

This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that adds a color filter on top of each sensor cell. This filter array is shown superimposed on a colorful photo.

Tapping __inside__ the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping __outside__ the image area ends the animation. A single tap __outside__ the image allows you to skip the animation.

The animation incidentally uses GPU core acceleration using the [Metal software framework](https://browser.geekbench.com/ios-benchmarks#metal).
trans-unit.note: Eighth paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source:
__Former Members__

The app can include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not shown, but you can enable displaying them in the _Preferences_ screen.

An easy way to get recent ex-members in the app is to simply keep their portfolio when they leave, but only mark the member as ex-member in the membership list.
trans-unit.target:
__Former Members__

The app can include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not shown, but you can enable displaying them in the _Preferences_ screen.

An easy way to get recent ex-members in the app is to simply keep their portfolio when they leave, but only mark the member as ex-member in the membership list.
trans-unit.note: Ninth paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app runs on iPhone and iPad and requires iOS 17.0 or higher. As most iOS users upgrade to the most recent iOS version possible, this means that the latest app version can support devices made in the last 6 or so years.
trans-unit.target: The app runs on iPhone and iPad and requires iOS 17.0 or higher. As most iOS users upgrade to the most recent iOS version possible, this means that the latest app version can support devices made in the last 6 or so years.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app depends heavily on various Apple software technologies. These include Swift (a programming language), SwiftUI (a user interface framework), Core Data (local data storage), Metal (graphics acceleration), and so-called _structured concurrency_ (for data fetching), Xcode (development tooling), and iOS itself.
trans-unit.target: The app depends heavily on various Apple software technologies. These include Swift (a programming language), SwiftUI (a user interface framework), Core Data (local data storage), Metal (graphics acceleration), and so-called _structured concurrency_ (for data fetching), Xcode (development tooling), and iOS itself.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The benefit of an iOS focus is that it allows the app's developers to focus on functionality rather than cross-platform compatibility.
trans-unit.target: The benefit of an iOS focus is that it allows the app's developers to focus on functionality rather than cross-platform compatibility.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The drawback, however, is the lack of Android support (for now). This is because the Android world has its own set of software technologies and tends to have more internal diversity. Apps that choose to support multiple platforms require more effort or require more technical compromises.
trans-unit.target: The drawback, however, is the lack of Android support (for now). This is because the Android world has its own set of software technologies and tends to have more internal diversity. Apps that choose to support multiple platforms require more effort or require more technical compromises.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: To put this into perspective, the top-6 software "platforms" are (largest first): web, Android, Windows, iOS, iPadOS, and MacOS. Only the very largest apps (like Word, Twitter, Minecraft, Chrome) cover the full range. Other famous apps cover only half: Photoshop (Windows, MacOS, iPadOS), WhatsApp (iPhone, Android, web - kind of), Pokémon Go (Android, iOS, iPadOS - kind of).
trans-unit.target: To put this into perspective, the top-6 software "platforms" are (largest first): web, Android, Windows, iOS, iPadOS, and MacOS. Only the very largest apps (like Word, Twitter, Minecraft, Chrome) cover the full range. Other famous apps cover only half: Photoshop (Windows, MacOS, iPadOS), WhatsApp (iPhone, Android, web - kind of), Pokémon Go (Android, iOS, iPadOS - kind of).
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The roadmap for additional future platform support will depend on uptake and help from the software community. MacOS and VisionOS both more or less work already. Support for Apple's tvOS is possible. However, a promising future step would be to support the automatic generation of web site pages using the same data sources used by the app. This would indirectly cover Android, PC, and more. And would benefit the clubs that need to maintain their lists.
trans-unit.target: The roadmap for additional future platform support will depend on uptake and help from the software community. MacOS and VisionOS both more or less work already. Support for Apple's tvOS is possible. However, a promising future step would be to support the automatic generation of web site pages using the same data sources used by the app. This would indirectly cover Android, PC, and more. And would benefit the clubs that need to maintain their lists.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: You can find this app on [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub). This allows other software developers to contribute. Getting more developers involved will speed things up, but also provides fresh ideas and ultimately improve continuity.
trans-unit.target: You can find this app on [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub). This allows other software developers to contribute. Getting more developers involved will speed things up, but also provides fresh ideas and ultimately improve continuity.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Welcome contributions include adding features, code improvements, ideas on architecture and interface definition, and possibly server-side functionality.
trans-unit.target: Welcome contributions include adding features, code improvements, ideas on architecture and interface definition, and possibly server-side functionality.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Contributions that _do not require coding_ are also welcome: beta testing via [TestFlight](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/testflight/id899247664), feature requests, translations, and - above all - adding support for more clubs.
trans-unit.target: Contributions that _do not require coding_ are also welcome: beta testing via [TestFlight](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/testflight/id899247664), feature requests, translations, and - above all - adding support for more clubs.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: There is a major ongoing transition to provide a clean, standardised interface to retrieve data per photo club. Such an interface is needed to load the data, but also to keep the data up to date. After all, membership data and portfolios change regularly. The original interface was a plug-in design with an adaptor per photo club. This is being replaced by a standard JSON-based interface to avoid having to update the source in order to onboard additional clubs.
trans-unit.target: There is a major ongoing transition to provide a clean, standardised interface to retrieve data per photo club. Such an interface is needed to load the data, but also to keep the data up to date. After all, membership data and portfolios change regularly. The original interface was a plug-in design with an adaptor per photo club. This is being replaced by a standard JSON-based interface to avoid having to update the source in order to onboard additional clubs.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: For Photo Club Waalre, an early prototype of this approach to loading data is already in use. The fact that the club exists is stored in a central (JSON) file. That file points to a membership list that is read from a HTML table on the club’s [website](https://www.FotogroepWaalre.nl). The portfolios are read from XML files generated by an Adobe Lightroom plug-in called [JuiceBox-Pro](https://www.juicebox.net/tour/). This plug-in allows the club to manage the portfolios per member using Lightroom (as a Lightroom "collection"). These collections can then be uploaded (ftp'ed) to the webserver via the Lightroom _Upload_ button. The uploaded information can then be downloaded from the web site when it is needed.
trans-unit.target: For Photo Club Waalre, an early prototype of this approach to loading data is already in use. The fact that the club exists is stored in a central (JSON) file. That file points to a membership list that is read from a HTML table on the club’s [website](https://www.FotogroepWaalre.nl). The portfolios are read from XML files generated by an Adobe Lightroom plug-in called [JuiceBox-Pro](https://www.juicebox.net/tour/). This plug-in allows the club to manage the portfolios per member using Lightroom (as a Lightroom "collection"). These collections can then be uploaded (ftp'ed) to the webserver via the Lightroom _Upload_ button. The uploaded information can then be downloaded from the web site when it is needed.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Software developers or other volunteers who are interested to help can contact us via GitHub, Facebook PM or LinkedIn.
trans-unit.target: Software developers or other volunteers who are interested to help can contact us via GitHub, Facebook PM or LinkedIn.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.target: This page lists all the photographers that this app knows about. A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name.
